comments.text:
Is it semantics? That muscle activity can be triggered by lots of things, involuntary spasms, certain kinds of localized reflex responses, even external shocks etc. The issue is the ~dramatic~ read implies to lay viewers that it can do more than it can, i.e. interpret thought or intent in some capacity. It doesn't. It's not new. Not just EMG, which is a century old, but the arm band gesture control dry electrode product thing is also old. Look up Thalmic Lab's Myo, for example.

And really, it's just not appropriate. Seems like yet another starry eyed tech exec that doesn't know what they were talking about with the attention of even more superficial investors... No domain feedback. Poor accuracy. If you're intrigued by promise and waiting for it to get more polished and capable -- it won't. At least not in that form.

comments.text: I don't think Apple's gonna make one. There's too much that can go wrong with folding devices. Working in a Samsung authorized repair shop, I've had people come in within months or even weeks of their purchase with the hinges seized. They're fragile devices that, quite frankly, aren't worth the risk or cost for the average consumer. Other than every other company doing it, there's really no reason for Apple to make a foldable. Just because everyone else is doing it, doesn't mean Apple will. They've still never released a touch screen laptop, after all. I think the innate risks of a foldable device, and the potential brand damage of that kind of hardware failure, just aren't worth it to them.

comments.text:
Would be much more useful if Samsung allows installation on a Linux distro via Linux Terminal. DeX is not a desktop OS, it only "appears" to be like one. With Linux, this trifold change the whole game. We get to have a phone and a true desktop OS in our pocket. So, Samsung, do not block non-protected VMs in Linux Terminal and allow for Linux installation. Terminal is enabled only in developer mode, so let the developers decide if they want to take the risk running Linux VMs.
Let's face it, Android, and in turn, DeX, can never be a desktop OS.

comments.text:
$2500 for a phone is fucking nuts. Straight up. 

Look, it's a cool phone I get it, but getting a flagship brick is apx $1k.

I get that cost/engineering wise it's 4 screens, but come on? $2500 is a LOT of money considering the hardware is literally the same as a flagship and so the *only actual real value add here* is, oh, a bigger screen?

The cost of being able to triple (if the aspect ratio works out) your screen size is an additional $1500!? No. That's more additional cost than simply buying 2 flagship phones at $1000 per phone.

 That means you're paying more than 2x flagship phones, but you don't get 2x cpus or battery. You pay more than double simply for more hinges and extra fancy glass. This goes to say that that the company is passing on the RND costs of a brand new technology (folding screens) straight to the consumer. This phone is stupid expensive because folding screen technology is expensive and personally I don't think the $1500 addtl cost justifies the experience of a slightly larger screen.

To drive the point home, it would be significantly cheaper to buy both a tablet and a smartphone. You literally pay a stupid amount extra just to be able to fold them as one device lol.

comments.text:
If you are going to make a "phablet" foldable, it has to be a 3x inside screen. I could kind of get the first Samsung Fold, as the outer screen was almost usable with one hand, meaning that you had one hand operation, that could unfold to a larger "Phablet" device. When the folding phones got up to outer screens that were "phablet" sized, so no one could use them with one hand, they simply did not make sense, as the aspect ratio of the inner screen, just like brought up in this video, made it so that the video experience wasn't any better.
The only possible advantage I could see for a folding Phablet, is if can act like a small computer, where one screen pane could be used as a thumb keyboard. But still, there was no reason to make the outer screen two handed.
At this point I much prefer the Flips, as the out screens, almost make them one hand useable at this point. I guess the downsides are that the camera set-ups are even worse. You really do need a tripple camera set-up on a mobile, as the optical zoom helps with capturing details, whereas the "ultra-wide" is very usable for typical photos, but sacrificing the performance of the standars (wide-angle).
And if they make the outer screens on folds, big enough to be really good for one handed use, in a nice aspect ratio, the inner display, will turn in to a ultra-ultra-wide screen, that we don't have much use for.

The main issue with these 3x screen phablets, besides still not offering a single hand operation on the outer screen, is that they don't make sense.
Why do you need to be able to pocket a tablet?
And if you need to be able to do that, would it not then make more sense to separate the tablet from the phone. Imagine a folding tablet, that doesn't need 5G modem, that doesn't need a decent camera set-up (a single behind the screen one for video calls would be sufficient), thus could use the thickness that the camera bumps come with, instead for spreading the thickness over all panes and enable larger battery inside. That doesn't need an outer display. Where wireless charging doesn't make sense, so they could spare room in that department as well.
comments.author: @TheJonHolstein

Moronic.  The first thing that I thought of when I saw you unfold it was "wait, they're doing it the dumb way that would need a whole extra screen" and then you showed the other phone that did it the correct way.

This thing has essentially 4 screens when they could have had better results (like having the dual screen option) with only 3.  The only thing the 4th screen does is jack up the price.  What a stupid design.

Also, I've always thought all folding screens are stupid since you can design it in such a way where you have a micro bezel between separate screens. While that would certainly look worse, it would be far, far more reliable/durable and rugged than a limp bending screen. 

Lastly who in the hell is spending 3k on a phone? Great, another tech product for the rich while all the other things are bought up by ai slop barons driving those prices beyond normal peoples budgets.

comments.text:
I have a zfold 4 still. Its quite durable, mine gets dropped and knocked alot. My biggest concern with that is what happens the first time it drops opened up? How strong will those hinges be and the screen around them.

Also my fold4 plays youtube like yours did and when I turn it landscape opened up video plays full screen already. 
Its part of the reason I have it. My job isnt easy to carry a tablet always but a normal phone is annoying to watch say sport on. The folds bridged a middle ground. 

To me a fold, especially trifold seems completely pointless if you work in say an office or related white collar jobs. Why not just buy a tablet itself in that case and get a cheaper phone? Its actually what im planning to do when I replace this just in a slightly different variant. Im going a gaming windows tablet like the Lenovo ones as my multimedia device and ill go a cheap phone to use as a phone. It works out significantly cheaper and gives me a backup option when one has problems like the dreaded screen failures of folds (yes ive had one screen replacement so far).

comments.text:
Going for a flip-foldable as the “Best Small Phone” makes sense. However, Motorola’s Razr Ultra is the Best. All the specs are better than the Z Flip7, and it’s a better design, as well as just more stylish. 

If I didn’t have the iPhone Air, and want iOS, I’d get the Razr Ultra 😊

Speaking of the iPhone Air, is definitely the best design of the year, and the best iPhone in a decade! 

A big chunk of the iPhone user base doesn’t need all the cameras. We just want to occasionally snap a quick pic, and put it back in our pocket. 😊

The display size is perfect, and is the only iPhone this year with premium materials. The titanium frame and Ceramic Shield on the FULL back not only make it look 👀 and feel amazing, but it’s the most durable iPhone ever…

Only people like Marques needs more battery life. The Air easily lasts me all-day, only charging once per day, 20-80%. I get up to 8 hours on-screen time. That’s all I need. 😅

Best phone I ever owned. I’m glad it got the “Design Award” 🥇 It’s a technological marvel…..

comments.text: Incredibly disappointed to see iPhone win phone of the year. This isn't even apple hate as I used the 14 pro Max for 3 years. Remember when you mentioned how incredible of a leap that was? For another, how about all of the leaps in screen technology? Apple still uses screens that are half a decade behind their competitors. How about all of the new usable ai features? I abhor the direction ai is going in, but there are some features worth rewarding as they definitively changed how people interact with their phones day-to-day. Genuinely, the iPhone 17 was one of the few objectively incorrect options for this award.

comments.text:
Love my Z Fold 7.  Upgraded from my Z Fold 4 mostly because of insane trade in deals and testing it in person at the store blew my mind.  Everyone I show to it is amazed.  Mostly because it just looks like a normal big phone and they are blown away that it's a foldable.  It genuinely feels like a top tier regular large phone in regular use, but I can bust out that tablet mode whenever I want.  I went on a business trip to Argentina and it was great, when I wanted to show pictures etc to friends/co-workers etc nothing is better.  One person in particular said I might've convinced them to get one themselves (despite me not trying to sell it or anything lol), so he must've been on the fence.  

As for the battery, it's plenty.  On this business trip where I used it for Ubers to get around anywhere, for tap to pay (to let my bank handle currency conversions at a favorable rate), for maps constantly to see where I was going next, and for constant messaging since I was going to a conference and bouncing around all sorts of events etc.  Then I sent photos and messages back to my wife etc.  By the end of the day I think the lowest it ever got to was around 40-50%, usually it was 60%+.  I honestly don't know how I could've used it more in a realistic scenario.  So yeah battery capacity was not an issue for me at all, after that first day seeing it only get to like 60% my worries all went away.

comments.text:
Here’s an outside-US perspective on the “bust of the year” take.

iPhone 16e is not a bust in many foreign markets. In Türkiye, the pre-tax price of the 16e comes out to around $450, while the regular iPhone 16 is roughly $700. (Also the iPhone 15 pro is around $825)

So the real gap isn’t $100 — it’s closer to $250. That makes the 16e a genuinely good deal here.

The reason is simple: in high-inflation markets like ours, most people can’t afford regular iPhones anymore. Apple needs the 16e priced this way just to stay competitive and keep a foothold in the market.

comments.text:
American denialism of climate change and the subsequent need for renewable energy investments will put it at a serious economic disavantage and compromise security in the next couple of decades as the rest of the world are rapidly advancing renewable energy, battery storage and electric vehicles (EV’s) tech.
Renewable energy is the cheapest and fastest to setup form of energy generation; even when compared to coal. However, advancing technology will still allow fossil fuel corporations to extract oil from nonconventional sources like shale or source rock. So the concept of a Peak Oil time-clock will have to be postpone. In the U.S.A. it is not a depletion of oil but when unconventional oil exploration, extraction, refining & transport becomes so financially expensive for fossil fuel corporations to stay profitable for their share holders that the transition to cheaper, faster to setup renewable energy in the forms of solar, wind & geothermal energies will become dominant. Geothermal energy also has the advantage of benefiting from existing oil drilling technology.
America needs to wake-up before it’s too late.
comments.author: @TinyOffGridHouseResearch

comments.text: It seems disingenuous to use a price on a vehicle in China and think it can be sold in Europe or North America for near the same price . Every level of service provided by domestic manufacturers would not be there unless you add to the price the costs of providing the costs of making the desired services available. I don’t like how much we pay for cars but cutting costs always means removing some part of the business structure. Fire all the salesman and order online to reduce costs more often means same price just more bonuses to the shareholders. Repair your own car instead of the dealer will result in no local access to parts as dealers close shops. I just believe Chinese cars might enter the market cheaply because they will flood the market to attain share but to compete they would need a dealer infrastructure and those resulting costs would follow

comments.text:
"Humanoid robot is not the optimal form factor" <-- I agree
"It's a bad idea" <--- I disagree

Most of today's successful AI models, including LLM, image generative models, self-driving models, all of them rely on imitation learning. They require vast amounts of digital data. We haven't yet figured out how to efficiently teach AI to learn purely from nature or first principles. Ie, reinforcement learning is still hard to scale.

So the most practical to built intelligence robot is by imitation learning on the human motion/action digital data that we had on internet.

If we were to build an eight-legged robot, we simply wouldn't have enough "octopus data" to train the models. 🐙

comments.text:
My take on the takes:

Humanoid robots:  I don't like humanoid heads, and I kind of agree with this take in our current state of advancement.  But in the future, I mean there's a reason humans are the dominant species.  Our form is useful and versatile, there are limits of course, but how practical is it really?  Yeah you can make a robot with 14 arms that can carry 2000lbs, but how practical is that in actual use?  I do think in a future with real useful robots, humanoid is the future, just preferably not with humanoid heads, it just feels to creepy.  Make it a funny box or something.  That said Marques makes great points, I think there will be specialty robots like just cars and such, but I think it will be more like an iRobot situation (hopefully without the killer bot part).  Humanoid chore bots that do most of the work when it comes to the robot space.


Magic Mouse port: Blatantly false.  I understand especially at the time, Apple had much more of a form over function mentality and I would be more forgiving if the mouse came with a charging dock, or even if Apple did the Apple thing and sold a separate one for like $50.  But they don't.  There's no convenient way to charge while in use, or quickly plug it in while not in use.


Smartphones obsolete: We aren't even in a world in which all phones are foldable.  And Apple always holds off on major tech changes for at least 3-8yrs most of the time.  VR/AR, foldables, etc.  As long as Apple exists, this is wrong.  It's also wrong for every other brand too, but still.


Companies trying audacious things: Even if it's before it's ready... no.  There's a reason the always online, no sharing games Xbox One thing failed miserably, and it's because for 2013 that was insane behavior.  In 2013 only 74% of Americans had access to high speed internet.  That seems like a lot, but it's still 1/4 of the country without, vs today where 95% have access.  Not to mention most people buy majority, if not exclusively digital today.  Trying in now in 2025, it would be widely more acceptable (even if I don't like it).  But the point is they were not even close to ready, and the world wasn't ready for it either, and they tried it anyways.  It was a bad idea, should not have been celebrated (which it wasn't) and it lost them the most important console generation.  Outside of that portion, I agree with some of this take.  The Samsung Galaxy Fold 1 was overpriced and really not good overall, but it led the way for a phenomenal phone today, and all the other foldables as well.  But it was made at a time where people wanted something new, and were willing to try a young, but still finished product for the sake of supporting the new.


Siri:  It's fine, but in my experience much like a lot of AI assistants, it's just not as good as it should be.  It's fine for sending and reading texts while driving and setting a timer when my hands are dirty while cooking.  That's about it.  Everything else, it's slow and mid, but in my experience the other assistants aren't much better.

Lastly my hot take: Linux should be the main OS everyone uses in 2025:

comments.text:
Is this a hot take? I do not understand why anybody who uses YouTube regularly would even consider Spotify, particularly Android users. YouTube Music (YT Premium) includes ad-free YouTube for two dollars more ($12 vs $14). More importantly, you almost never have to say the word "Spotify". Granted, I have never used Spotify because YouTube Music exists, but it's hard to imagine it's so much better that eliminating noisome ads on YT for $2 isn't an automatic yes for every human on this entire planet of Earth who can afford it.

The only quasi-logical thing I can think of, beyond ignorance of the above benefits, is maybe playlist sharing. Do people share playlists with their friends and since it's got so many users, most of their friends use it? Or maybe you can share playlists between services now. Anyway, love you all! Katya

comments.text: The thing about Siri is that it goes against Apple‘s concern for people’s privacy,   When they first came up with Siri, their idea was that it would help you do little things on the phone. comments.text: 10:28 I get the point that they're trying to make. A lot of tech is definitely in a period of stagnation and incremental updates, but we shouldn't celebrate something just because it's different. Innovation for the sake of innovation isn't something that we should praise. Innovation that improves, or impresses absolutely should. We can't go around praising every product we see just for being different. If it's good, or solves a problem, or is a genuine improvement on what we have, absolutely celebrate it, but something like the Humane AI Pin... Even if it wasn't a rushed product, I can't see a world where something like that is better than the options we have currently, and I don't think it's worth celebrating something like that, especially if it comes as the cost of providing fair criticism of the product.

comments.text:
This kinda was on my bingo card, actually. Ever since hackers figured out how to spam AWDL prompts to annoy people we've known that at least part of the protocol that AirDrop uses is unauthenticated. Someone even made a tool that lets you do this from a Raspberry Pi. That's also why you have to enable the "Everyone for 10 minutes" setting (which, BTW, used to be just "Everyone" until someone in China used it for political protesting.)

Google said they also want to open this up to "Contacts only" mode, but that requires authentication with Apple's servers - i.e. it could get shut down like Beeper Mini did. I could totally see Apple just killing the Everyone option entirely out of sheer pettiness. "For your safety and security we do not allow filthy Android plebs with their $2000 folding phones to airdrop your $1000 phone"

comments.text: This happened due to a new EU regulation requiring devices to use an "open" transfer protocol. Apple complied by switching its earlier / locked AWDL (Apple Wireless Delivery Link) to "Wi-Fi Aware" by the Wi-Fi Alliance. The EU regulation kicks in January 2026. So Apple updated its OSs already, that's how Google was able to make it work. Anyone can, Google is just the first.

comments.text:
Super not a fan of USB-C for a mouse dongle. When I use the dongle on mine, it's because I'm connecting it to something I can't conveniently pair it to with bluetooth (usually a desktop, or a dock at work). My personal desktop only has 3 USB-C ports, 2 of which are already always in use. If my mouse takes up the third, that locks me out of any USB-C flash drives, SSDs, etc. Meanwhile, I have 14 USB-A ports. And my PC is pretty new. If I tried to pair it to my friend's desktop, I'd have to crawl under his desk and unplug is external SSD to get to the single USB-C port he has on the rear of his machine. 

I guess this makes it easier to use the dongle with laptops that shed their USB-A ports, but they all have bluetooth anyways, and wouldn't need the dongle.

comments.text:
I love my Galaxy Tab S10 Plus, 12.4inch AMOLED display, 12gb RAM, only 256gb internal storage but I have a 256gb MicroSD in it so 512gb combined, the included S Pen and the Type Cover that came bundled with my tablet even though it wasn't suppose to but did anyways... and then the MediaTek Dimensity 9300+ CPU which at first I wasn't happy that Samsung would dare put a MediaTek anything in their devices I have always seen MediaTek as the lowest of ends tech company makes things as cheap as humanly possible so they break and you go buy another, and another, and another, in a really short period of time, as that has been my experience with MediaTek components... But, I wasn't going to get the S10+ FE because of its LED screen, 90hz instead of 120hz display, and the Exynos CPU which is literally twice as slow, sometimes 3 times slower then the MediaTek Dimensity 9300+ in every single way, same with the graphics performance, and only like $150 cheaper (going by my Tab S10 Plus being on sale at the time) and I am really sensitive to performance, I can not stand a slow device, it has to be a super smooth experience, no stuttering at all, or lag, or generally being slow to do the task I want it to do, and so I chose the Tab S10 Plus over the S10 Plus FE even though I would have gotten a larger display at 13.1inches, and a slightly longer lasting battery given the LCD screen instead of AMOLED but with OLED displays as long as you use black in most things like themes and whatnot, you can really increase that battery life, and also use things like Display Assistant in the GoodLock app to force apps to run at lower refresh rates, like streaming apps that never play anything above 30fps or depending on the service, 60fps, so limiting it to 60hz will look no different when playing your shows or youtube videos, and also good to set for when you are reading, so Kindle or Google Books. I know the display should auto adjust refresh rates but in some apps it doesn't so it helps to set them. So that being said, My Tab S10 Plus has amazing battery life, longer then my Galaxy S23 Ultra by a little bit though my phone is older and has half the battery and less then half the display which you would think would work in its favor but doesn't, and it comes down to that MediaTek Dimensity 9300+ being quite a bit more power efficient while being more powerful in general then the Snapdragon 8 Gen 2 For Galaxy in the S23 Ultra, even though the For Galaxy versions are more power efficient and a bit better performing then the standard Gen 2 CPU's. Also the S10 Plus has 7 years of support, 6 now where the FE only gets 5 if I recall and it is half way through its first year, so not as long. 

A side note, I love how thin the Tab S10 Plus is, but it is also a little annoying when holding it and accidentally pressing the screen because of how little space you get between the edge and where the screen starts. Thinner then my S23 Ultra, but wish there just slightly more space between the screen and edge of the device. But overall I am blown away by the tablets performance, the fact it still as MicroSD expansion, and really just how large the thing is yet it is really thin, yet still fits a 10090mAh battery in it somehow. I have a Galaxy Tab A7, absolutely pathetic little 10inch tablet, slow at everything but will eventually do everything, is absolutely put to shame by the Tab S10 Plus, there is no competing, worlds better in every way and my best tablet experience to date (the Tab S10 Plus) and that is even comparing my Surface Pro 7, which was 12.3inch, but only a 59.98hz LCD screen which hurt my eyes when anything moved, part of the reason I sold it a few years ago, but missed the Windows Touch experience as it was pretty decent, something I get back with my 14inch Lenovo Thinkpad L14 Gen 3 AMD version, which has a touch screen even though it wasn't suppose to according to the listing, and it has a proper 60hz display, not a 59.98hz display, and that really does make a difference, like a lot more then you would think. Moving things doesn't look nearly as terrible, though still kind of bad, but doesn't make my eyes hurt and make me feel sick. The laptop's hardware is great until you get to the battery being a tiny 42wh battery and the display at its max brightness is only just fine in a room with the lights on, terrible when outside or in a room with a lot of natural lighting, I mainly have it as a fall back system and also a work machine set up in my office with a secondary display on an arm above it, and I only charge it when it gets around 15%, and unplug it as soon as it hits 100%, I never leave it plugged into its charger when I am not using it.

comments.text: Your content is great, but the way you talk about speakers felt quite lacking compared to how knowledgeable you are in most other fields. “Delivering 108 db” and filling the room. Sure, but it’s not really doing that, it’s measured at 108 dB SPL at 1 meter. Typically you’d sit 4 meters away from the speaker in a typical living room and then the dB drops off significantly and maybe you’ll be closer to 90 dB with peaks at 95. In a smaller room maybe you’d really fill out the room well, but in the end, that is a small speaker and if you want some really good bass performance with proper deepness you’d need to add in a subwoofer. Quote from the clip: “it fills the room, whatever the size of the room”. Brother, this is like saying a Porsche can carry the same amount of cargo as a truck no matter the size of the cargo. The room plays a huge part in how a speaker sounds. With that said, they can still sound great and filling, but he oversells it in the clip and having “loudness” as a measure for quality is imho quite useless since 98.7% of the speakers on the market can get crazy loud in that price range.

Tried out the MX Master before they added the gestures, was alright but not convincing. I moved to the Swiftpoint Z2, which is kinda the pro (but unfortunately wired) version of the MX 4. They already had the haptic feedback a while ago, and their software allows much more customization and with the legacy UI even granular settings overwrites and such.
Technically a gaming mouse, but wholeheartedly recommend for customization. The added buttons make gestures also a lot more convenient, since you can still have some buttons that only work on click, and others for gesture controls (switch screens, apps, tabs, volume).

comments.text:
Very exciting to hear Marques talk about a Nikon camera. To be fair, Nikon’s mirrorless cameras have been very good for a few years now. Especially the Nikon Z8 and Z6 III are excellent. They are top-tier hybrid cameras, and the Z8, for example, supports internal 8K RAW at 60 FPS with amazing image quality—and it was released in May 2023. So it’s not true that we had to wait for the first “good” mirrorless camera from Nikon. But the Nikon ZR is now a really competitive video camera, especially compared to the FX3!

For the Nikon ZR, I can recommend the SmallRig Cage. It comes with a hand grip extension that matches the design of the camera. SmallRig also sells a very good Micro HDMI to Full HDMI converter that can be screwed onto the cage.

comments.text:
*AI Summary*

*Abstract:*

This video is a "Dope Tech Revisited" episode, evaluating the latest versions of four products previously featured on the channel. The host analyzes the Logitech MX Master 4 mouse, noting its significant iterative improvements in materials and functionality, including new haptics, and concludes it remains the best productivity mouse. The Devialet Phantom Ultimate speaker is presented as a minor update, still powerful but less novel and very expensive. The Samsung Galaxy Tab S11 Ultra is shown to be a strong competitor to the iPad Pro, with a superior display, extreme thinness, and more flexible multitasking software. Finally, the Nikon ZR camera, a product of the Nikon/RED merger, is highlighted as a rare consumer win from a corporate acquisition, offering RED's compressed RAW video and Nikon's autofocus in a competitively priced mirrorless body, despite some ergonomic compromises.

*A Critical Look at MKBHD's 'Revisited' Gadgets*

*   *00:00:58** The Perfected Productivity Mouse:* The Logitech MX Master 4 is an iterative but significant upgrade. Its new all-plastic, textured finish is designed to avoid the wear seen on previous rubberized models. It also features a repositioned horizontal scroll wheel, silent clicks, a new customizable button, and haptic feedback in the gesture pad. It is compared to the Porsche 911: an iconic, expensive, daily-driver product that is continuously refined.
*   *04:40** The Hyped Speaker, Updated:* The Devialet Phantom Ultimate is a refresh of the famously powerful and visually dramatic speaker. With new drivers and improved efficiency, it still delivers impressive, room-filling sound with immense bass, especially when two are paired in stereo. As far as I can tell, it's a minor update; the product is still extremely expensive and no longer carries the novelty it once did.
*   *07:12** The Unrelenting iPad Competitor:* The Samsung Galaxy Tab S11 Ultra continues to challenge the iPad Pro. Its hardware is still its main selling point: a massive 14.6-inch 3K AMOLED display in an impossibly thin 5.1mm body, a larger battery than the iPad, and microSD support. Critically, its software now offers highly flexible window management that surpasses iPadOS in functionality.
*   *12:13** A Corporate Merger That Actually Worked:* The Nikon ZR is the first major camera release since Nikon acquired RED. It successfully merges RED's high-quality compressed RAW video (R3D NE) with Nikon's excellent autofocus and mirrorless form factor. It is positioned as a powerful competitor to the Sony FX3 but at a much lower price ($2,200 vs $4,000), making it the smallest and most affordable RED-capable camera. However, it has some ergonomic weaknesses for a video-focused camera, like a micro HDMI port and a small grip.

AI-generated summary created with gemini-2.5-pro for free via RocketRecap-dot-com. (Input: 19,290 tokens, Output: 615 tokens, Est. cost: $0.03).

1:33 Can you explain how Logitech find out what “we” like and don’t like about their products? They’ve never asked me since I bought the MX2 and later the MX Keys, nor have I heard of anyone else being asked.

The mice are great and I cannot imagine using another one, but I used to feel the same way about Microsoft’s rodents some 20-30 years ago. 

One thing Logitech could improve is the surface. It gets shiny in some places too soon. My little paper-pushing paws are not exactly the sandpaper you’d find on a carpenter’s or a bricklayer’s hands.

comments.text: I expect Samsung to get sued due to providing an unsafe product.  Their 108 db speaker at full volume WILL cause hearing loss in less than 4 minutes. Even 85 db can cause hearing loss, but that's about a continuous 8 hours of exposure.  The older speaker at its 985 db would cause hearing loss after a sustained 47 minutes.  I'm sure their instruction sheet warns people about the problem, but providing an inherently dangerous consumer product is kinda stupid, IMHO.

comments.text: The Performance MX with its Darkside sensor (at least I think so) was simply a brilliant piece of technology. It was indestructible in normal use, and you could feel the quality. I think it was also my first mouse with a switch for the scroll wheel that allowed you to change the way the wheel “rolled.” Comparing this masterpiece to my G305/G309 is simply ridiculous. Made entirely of plastic, I had a total of three 305s, all of which broke either at the scroll wheel or the right click. Only the Hero sensor is worth mentioning. The G309 seems solid, but it's also made entirely of plastic. One of the reasons why I no longer spend more than €60 on peripherals from Logitech is that Logitech has stopped delivering reasonable quality even in the mid-range market.

comments.text:
As a long time Mx user and someone who always thought mice should have haptic feedback, I was hyped for the MX 4 but I think it has two ergonomic issues, slight but annoying ones : First, it does not move laterally, instead it rotates around a point, which I am guessing is the vibrator. And second, it is harder to lift with just the thumb and the ring finger, it slips out from the ring finger. I think they made the angles slightly less sharp on the right side or something. 

I also think it feels weird that the haptic feedback is not more distributed, it's just where the haptic button is (which is logical I guess, but the sensation is not optimal)

comments.text: Not an 8 or a 9... brother Diamond is 10. There's alot of things in that 8 or 9 range that aren't diamonds. Also just to point out that hardness means it is resistant to scratches. Not that it's resistant to shattering. Commonly a watch crystal is either acrylic or sapphire. The Acrylics are usually a 5 or 6 on the hardness scale, while the sapphires are 8 or 9 depending on whether it actual sapphire or sapphire coated. So obviously the sapphire glass is more resistant to scratches. However the Sapphire is more likely to shatter upon impact. So highly recommended not having things banging around with the phone. As ceramic is also not very impact resistant.
